I changed "- Press %s to %s multiview mode" to "Press %s to toggle multiview mode", so we need to update the translation file. I don't want to make eight separate commits for this, so update the translation here and when it's finished we will commit it in a single commit: 
{
        english         "Press %s to toggle multiview mode" 
        french          "Appuyez sur %s pour basculer en mode MultiVue"
        german          "Drücke %s um in den Multiview Modus zu wechseln"
        italian         "Press %s to toggle multiview mode"
        spanish         "Press %s to toggle multiview mode"
        polish          "Wcisnij %s aby przelaczyc tryb wielowidoku"
        dutch           "Druk %s voor TOGGLE Multiview Modus" <- update
        czech           "Stiskni %s k prepnutí sledovaní více hrácu"
        russian         "Press %s to toggle multiview mode"
        finnish         "Press %s to toggle multiview mode"
        danish          "Tryk %s for TOGGLE flerbetragtnings tilstand" <- update
}
_EDIT:_ I see I left it as "Press %s to %s multiview mode" in source:src/cgame/cg_draw.c, so when the translation is finished, we have to remember to change that to "Press %s to toggle multiview mode" EDIT: german and french (IRA) _EDIT:_ Polish done.

Radegast wrote: > 
przełączać
"ł", "ą" and "ć" allowed? Does it mean ET:L support full ISO/IEC 8859?

Dragon wrote:
> Radegast wrote:
> > [...] 
> "ł", "ą" and "ć" allowed? Does it mean ET:L support full ISO/IEC 8859?

No.
Also, imo better translation is "przełączyć" not "przełączać". Because context of this sentence suggests single action (Press [once] -> "Wciśnij", not Press [many times] -> "Naciskaj").

Hello,

Could you update the French line from:
french          "Appuyez sur %s pour basculer le mode multivue" <- check

To:
french          "Appuyez sur %s pour basculer en mode MultiVue"

?

It would be more correct, or said this way it would mean "Toggle from multiview mode to *nothing*" :)

Mateos wrote:
> .. 
> Could you update the French line from: It would be more correct, or said this way it would mean "Toggle from multiview mode to *nothing*" :)

done.

Is there a possibility that I could help with the Finnish translations?

At least the translation for this "Press %s to toggle multiview mode" would be "Paina %s vaihtaaksesi multiview tilaan"

Saukko wrote:
> Is there a possibility that I could help with the Finnish translations?
Of course :D ... 1st. step: Download http://www.etlegacy.com/projects/etlegacy/repository/revisions/master/entry/etmain/scripts/translation.cfg and edit finish translation in the specific row. 
Make sure your file is saved with char encoding ISO/IEC 8859-1. It's easy to set with good editors (notepad++ etc ...).
Hey! I found some mistakes in polish translation but now It's fixed.

tu ... it's committed

@Saukko please start with the latest translation.cfg ;)

Good evening,

Updated the French translation to something more... French :) "Warmup" was translated by 2 different words top or down the script for instance, now unified, and few more adjustments.

I am facing a little problem while translating some of the points. Since the form of the Finnish sentences are sometimes quite complicated, I need to know the context to be sure about the translation. Here is an example:

"(WARMUP) Match begins in:" Does it mean that the match starts after a certain time which would make the translation like this: "(LÄMMITTELY) Peli alkaa: kuluttua", otherwise it would just be "(LÄMMITTELY) Peli alkaa:"

Also I would like to know that some of these points do have words where both have a capital letter as first. F.e. "Connection Interrupted" and what I saw some of the translations in other languages it might be like this: "Verbindung unterbrochen". So does it matter does the second word have a capital letter?

I will be translating some of those today but the rest tomorrow after I know the answer to these two questions. ;)

-*S

After this you have a countdown, from a certain amount of seconds to 0 and then the match starts.

On my side, where there were capitals, I restored them in the French version, to be as much accurate as possible :)

I would like to point out few small things:

- In french we use a space before and after 2-part symbols like these: ":", "?", "!" (there are more) as I did in the first french translation (refs 38989d2) and some spaces after ":" were removed...
- About capital letters, I don't know how it is in other languages but in french they should only be used at beginning  and for proper nouns and for some few other cases only.

saukko write:
> Also I would like to know that some of these points do have words where both have a capital letter as first. ...
boutetnico wrote:
> - About capital letters, I don't know how it is in other languages but in french they should only be used at beginning  and for proper nouns and for some few other cases only.
Finally it's up to the translator/community. We just can't change the english text part without messing up 'vanilla' translation compatibility. 
The current english texts in translation.cfg are exactly used in the GPL code and if mod authors don't delete the translation function it'll get translated in mods too.
"Connection Interrupted" is an english typo in my eyes.

boutetnico wrote:
> - In french we use a space before and after 2-part symbols like these: ":", "?", "!" (there are more) as I did in the first french translation (refs 38989d2) and some spaces after ":" were removed...
> - About capital letters, I don't know how it is in other languages but in french they should only be used at beginning  and for proper nouns and for some few other cases only.

I'm not sure about a space before "!" and "?" (But +1 for a space after), but for ":" I agree.

English and French almost behave the same for capitals, one diff could be in this very sentence that French would not have a capital as it doesn't begin it; Some people write for instance "Depth of Field" in the middle of a sentence while others would just write "depth of field", as said Irata it's up to the translator, but better respect conventions :)

Ok, I am nearly finished with the translation (damn it took long) but there are couple of things I would like to point out:

- The context for "SCORE"? There are enough many translations for that word. It would be nice to know does it mean the final "SCORE", the current "SCORE" or a point "SCORE" f.e. 1-0?
- Translation for "You swapped places with"? This is at the moment impossible to translate in Finnish if there is no object to whom swapping is concentrated in. The traslation to Finnish would be "Vaihdoit paikkaa pelaajan [player name] kanssa". There is no other way to translate the English sentence. So is there a posibility to add something to make my translation possible?
- The context for "Press '%s' for YES, or '%s' for No"? This is an easy one to translate. If this is about voting, then the translation is easy. Well it would be anyway.
- The contexts for "Bonus Life! Deploying in %d seconds" and "No more deployments this round"? Does it mean that some sort of object will be deploying? Or There will be no more some object? I never seen these in-game so it is difficult to know the meaning. ;)
- The context for "ROUND"? Well there are only two translations I could come up with. I open this with an example: It lasts always the same amount of time f.e. 10 minutes. And the other one: Doesn't always last the same amount of time.

Hope to get some answers. :>

EDIT: And I noticed that some of German translations are in Italian. I guess somebody could check those then?

-*S

Round: In Stopwatch mode, you play alternatively Axis and Allies. For instance:
ROUND 1 - Team 1 vs Team 2, defines the clock time
ROUND 2 - Team 2 vs Team 1, Obj: beat the Round 1 clock

Hopes it answers :) For the other ones I'm not sure; Does the Yes/No thingy is to create a Fireteam then choose if it is public or private? Or is it for the Vote system? Is "deployment" here used for the Last Man Standing mode (Which I believe), for which you have a limited number of respawns?

Mateos wrote:
> I'm not sure about a space before "!" and "?" (But +1 for a space after), but for ":" I agree.

You can check this: http://www.la-ponctuation.com
